update.description:
This adds a button to show a terminal for each device showing its logging output and any printlines etc.

This makes it easier to debug devices, as well as making very basic devices where they just say on the terminal what they're doing instead of writing GUI code to do so. Lincoln was mentioning that this is something that would be desirable given the number of single-purpose scripts being written that really ought to be device tabs but that nobody really cares to write a GUI for.

This does mean that per-device logging output will not be present in the terminal if running BLACS from the terminal - only logging output from the main process. However, the BLACS log file will still contain logging from all processes.

If this is considered too big a drawback, I can add an option to OutputBox to make it duplicate any output it receives to the stdout/stderr of the current process.

Terminal visibility and splitter size is saved and loaded to the BLACS settings file. This required me to introduce `DeviceTab.get_builtin_save_data()` and `DeviceTab.restore_builtin_save_data()` since `get_save_data` and `restore_save_data` are not required to call the base class implementation, so I could not put it there. But it stores the settings in the same dict (with names prefixed by an underscore).

This change depends on [labscript_utils pull request 40](#!/labscript_suite/labscript_utils/pull-requests/40/), otherwise the subprocesses have stdout set to devnull and won't produce any output.

Screenshot (button is up the top next to the restart button):

![blacs_terminal.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/9pKE7ad/images/3533854408-blacs_terminal.png)
update.title: Worker terminals

update.title: Worker terminals

content.raw:
Pretty sure you could restore the settings \(call `Tab.restore_builtin_save_data` or whatever\) from `Tab.__init__` because all the relevant UI elements exist by the end of object construction. We only go through the complicated set of methods in `DeviceTab` because we want the user to control part of `DeviceTab.__init__` and we need to ensure things happen in the right order. I don't see that we have that constraint here because a user/developer shouldn't be doing anything that would require that separation.

EDIT: Oh I see, that doesn't catch the case of restoring front panel settings from a H5 file when BLACS is running...
content.html:
Pretty sure you could restore the settings (call Tab.restore_builtin_save_data or whatever) from Tab.__init__ because all the relevant UI elements exist by the end of object construction. We only go through the complicated set of methods in DeviceTab because we want the user to control part of DeviceTab.__init__ and we need to ensure things happen in the right order. I don't see that we have that constraint here because a user/developer shouldn't be doing anything that would require that separation.

EDIT: Oh I see, that doesn't catch the case of restoring front panel settings from a H5 file when BLACS is running...

This makes it easier to debug devices, as well as making very basic devices where they just say on the terminal what they're doing instead of writing GUI code to do so. Lincoln was mentioning that this is something that would be desirable given the number of single-purpose scripts being written that really ought to be device tabs but that nobody really cares to write a GUI for.

This does mean that per-device logging output will not be present in the terminal if running BLACS from the terminal - only logging output from the main process. However, the BLACS log file will still contain logging from all processes.

If this is considered too big a drawback, I can add an option to OutputBox to make it duplicate any output it receives to the stdout/stderr of the current process.

But it stores the settings in the same dict (with names prefixed by an underscore).

This change depends on [labscript_utils pull request 40](#!/labscript_suite/labscript_utils/pull-requests/40/), otherwise the subprocesses have stdout set to devnull and won't produce any output.

update.title: Worker terminals

content.raw: Sure, I agree. The only thing would be  `DeviceTab.update_from_settings()`, it would still need to call `self.restore_builtin_save_data()`, unless I implement the method in  the `Tab` base class and have `DeviceTab.update_from_settings()` call the base class implementation.
content.html: Sure, I agree. The only thing would be DeviceTab.update_from_settings(), it would still need to call self.restore_builtin_save_data(), unless I implement the method in the Tab base class and have DeviceTab.update_from_settings() call the base class implementation.

content.raw: Fair enough. I'll open an issue about possibly merging these in the future so people can discuss ways that it might work.
content.html: Fair enough. I'll open an issue about possibly merging these in the future so people can discuss ways that it might work.

content.raw:
I'm a bit confused as to why some of the code is in device\_base\_class.py. This seems to be a change to how we manage the display of output from workers, which are managed by tab\_base\_classes.py \(and indeed the ui file used directly by tab\_base\_classes is the one you've modified\). The base class should really be able to be subclassed directly, without needing to use `DeviceTab`. If it's just about save/restore of data, maybe we need to include something along those lines in `Tab` so that this change can be entirely contained within tab\_base\_classes.py

I suspect that change would also result in this pull request becoming compatible with the plugin tabs pull request.
content.html:
I'm a bit confused as to why some of the code is in device_base_class.py. This seems to be a change to how we manage the display of output from workers, which are managed by tab_base_classes.py (and indeed the ui file used directly by tab_base_classes is the one you've modified). The base class should really be able to be subclassed directly, without needing to use DeviceTab. If it's just about save/restore of data, maybe we need to include something along those lines in Tab so that this change can be entirely contained within tab_base_classes.py

I suspect that change would also result in this pull request becoming compatible with the plugin tabs pull request.

content.raw: I think they ought to remain separate things, at least for the moment, since I can't think of a way to unify them without the drawbacks you mention. The terminal will display all logging messages, not just errors, whereas the top popup box will only display errors that were returned to the parent process, as well as errors in the parent process itself. For normal devices the terminal is debugging output that won't be visible most of the time, and won't pop up unless called upon, so there is not always visible duplication at least.
content.html: I think they ought to remain separate things, at least for the moment, since I can't think of a way to unify them without the drawbacks you mention. The terminal will display all logging messages, not just errors, whereas the top popup box will only display errors that were returned to the parent process, as well as errors in the parent process itself. For normal devices the terminal is debugging output that won't be visible most of the time, and won't pop up unless called upon, so there is not always visible duplication at least.

That can be fixed!

labscript_utils PR 41

content.raw:
I'm wondering if we can't unify this somehow with the existing textbox that displays the exceptions?

I'm thinking it would then display the logging information for both the state machine and worker. Maybe it's too complicated because you don't want exceptions to get buried in worker logging messages \(say if a thread is still running in the worker\) and I'm not sure how you would display "worker has not responded for x seconds" messages in a way that made sense \(and didn't get buried\) but it seems kind of weird and non-intuitive to have two separate text boxes displaying various bits of information about the tab...
content.html:
I'm wondering if we can't unify this somehow with the existing textbox that displays the exceptions?

I'm thinking it would then display the logging information for both the state machine and worker. Maybe it's too complicated because you don't want exceptions to get buried in worker logging messages (say if a thread is still running in the worker) and I'm not sure how you would display "worker has not responded for x seconds" messages in a way that made sense (and didn't get buried) but it seems kind of weird and non-intuitive to have two separate text boxes displaying various bits of information about the tab...

content.raw:
This looks really nice! 

I did a bit of testing and other than a few exceptions due to Plugin Tabs \(which are not mainline yet\) not having a function`get_builtin_save_data` everything worked as advertised.

It is a bit confusing that exceptions and error messages are not posted in red but FutureWarnings are. But this can not really be helped I guess as they are printed to the stdout and not to stderr.
content.html:
This looks really nice!

I did a bit of testing and other than a few exceptions due to Plugin Tabs (which are not mainline yet) not having a functionget_builtin_save_data everything worked as advertised.

It is a bit confusing that exceptions and error messages are not posted in red but FutureWarnings are. But this can not really be helped I guess as they are printed to the stdout and not to stderr.

Lincoln was mentioning that this is something that would be desirable given the number of single-purpose scripts being written that really ought to be device tabs but that nobody really cares to write a GUI for.

This does mean that per-device logging output will not be present in the terminal if running BLACS from the terminal - only logging output from the main process. However, the BLACS log file will still contain logging from all processes.

If this is considered too big a drawback, I can add an option to OutputBox to make it duplicate any output it receives to the stdout/stderr of the current process.

This required me to introduce `DeviceTab.get_builtin_save_data()` and `DeviceTab.restore_builtin_save_data()` since `get_save_data` and `restore_save_data` are not required to call the base class implementation, so I could not put it there. Screenshot (button is up the top next to the restart button):
